awd_titl_txt: Support for the Core Research Activities and Studies of the Computer Science and Telecommunications Board
awd_abstract_narration:
This CISE award funds part of the core operations of the Computer Science and Telecommunications Board (CSTB) of the National Academy of Sciences for a period of 5 years. The CSTB provides objective, scholarly analysis, blending expertise in computer science, electrical engineering, telecommunications, and various applications and impacts of information technology (IT). CSTB's work is known and used by a wide and growing circle of agencies, officials, and experts in the field. CSTB has come to be seen as an authoritative source on IT trends, IT policies, and their implications for broader public policy. CSTB delivers its reports and provides briefings to key decision-makers and practitioners in the research, education, and policy-making communities. Its study groups engage significant numbers of women, minorities, and people from across the country. Core support enables it to plan for, oversee, and follow up on projects, and to be forward-thinking and proactive in formulating new activities. 

This funding provides for the core research activities and studies of the CSTB.  Through its membership of national leaders and industry, CSTB has an ambitious program of activities addressing the health of U.S. computer science, telecommunications, and their applications. CSTB engages experts from the entire IT community in mixed collaborative groups, developing ideas, explanations, assessments, and recommendations reflecting diverse points of view and rigorous peer review.  It is a focal point for engaging the research community in the development of new research agendas and in raising the level of policy debate.  Core support enables CSTB to plan, oversee, and follow up on projects and students and continue to provide strategic leadership in an area of critical importance to the nation.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided partial support for the activities of the Computer Science and Telecommunications Board of the National Academies.  CSTB  provides objective, nonpartisan, scholarly analysis, blending expertise in computer science (CS), electrical engineering, telecommunications, and various applications and impacts of information technology (IT).  It engaged experts from across the IT community in mixed collaborative groups, developing ideas, explanations, assessments, and recommendations reflecting diverse points of view and rigorous peer review.  Largely separately supported but overseen and otherwise enabled in part by this award, CSTB issued reports covering future research directions, impact and implications of research, applications of IT, human resources in IT, and public policy impacts:

Studies

Quantum Computing: Progress and Prospects (2018) assesses the current progress and possible future pathways towards developing a general-purpose quantum computer as well as its potential implications. (Sponsored by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, ODNI, and carried up in collaboration with the Intelligence Community Studies Board.)

Securing the Vote: Protecting American Democracy (2018) recommends steps that the federal government, state and local governments and election administrators can take to make elections more secure, accessible, reliable, and verifiable. (Sponsored by the Carnegie Corporation of New York, the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, the National Academy of Sciences? W. K. Kellogg Foundation Fund, and the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine?s Presidents? Circle Fund. Led by the Committee on Science Technology and Law in collaboration with CSTB.)

Data Science for Undergraduates: Opportunities and Options (2018) offers a vision for the emerging discipline of data science at the undergraduate level and outlines considerations and approaches for academic institutions and others to help guide the ongoing transformation of the field. (Sponsored by NSF.)

Decrypting the Encryption Debate: A Framework for Decision-Makers (2018) provides a framework for evaluating proposals to provide authorized government access to the plaintext of encrypted communications and stored data. (Sponsored by NSF and the Hewlett and MacArthur Foundations.)

Assessing and Responding to the Growth of Computer Science Undergraduate Enrollments (2018) examines the increasing enrollments in undergraduate CS courses and majors, underlying drivers, and associated diversity implications, with recommendations about how best to respond. (Sponsored by NSF.)

Emergency Alert and Warning System: Current Knowledge and Future Research Directions (2018) explores how a more effective national alert and warning system might be created and sets forth a research agenda to advance the nation?s alert and warning capabilities. (Sponsored by the Department of Homeland Security.)

Foundational Cybersecurity Research: Improving Science, Engineering, and Institutions (2017) focuses on foundational research strategies and on building collaborative links across disciplines and between research and practice. (Sponsored by NSA on behalf of the Special Cyber Operations Research & Engineering interagency working group.)

Information Technology and the U.S. Workforce: Where are We and Where Do We Go from Here? (2017) explores current and emerging information technology capabilities and their interplay with various dimensions of work, and highlights areas where new research and data would help to improve understanding and inform future decision-making. (Sponsored by NSF.)

Workshops

Implications of Artificial Intelligence for Cybersecurity: Proceedings of a Workshop (2019) explores applications of artificial intelligence  (AI) technologies to cybersecurity as well as the security of AI systems themselves. (Sponsored by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.)

Key Operational Characteristics and Functionalities of a State-of-the-Art Patient Scheduling System (2019) discusses evolving technologies and approaches for medical appointment scheduling and meeting the needs of patients in the Department of Veterans Affairs Healthcare System. (Sponsored by the Veteran?s Administration. Led by Board on Health Care Services in collaboration with CSTB.)

Beyond Spectre:  Confronting New Technical and Policy Challenges (2019) discusses the implications of recently discovered architectural vulnerabilities in microprocessors. (A workshop convened under the Cyber Resilience Forum.)

Recoverability as a First-Class Security Objective (2018) discusses how to restore normal operations and security following an attack or failure of software or hardware. (A workshop convened under the Cyber Resilience Forum.)

Opportunities from the Integration of Simulation and Data Science (2018) examines current and emerging science applications that span simulation and data-driven science, their characteristics, and future approaches for cyberinfrastructure to support them.

Software Update as a Mechanism for Resilience and Security (2017) discusses practices mechanisms, policies, and technologies associated with software updates. (A workshop convened under the Cyber Resilience Forum.)

Cryptographic Agility and Interoperability (2017) discusses drivers for cryptographic agility and its technical and societal implications. (A workshop convened under the Cyber Resilience Forum.)
